resources.string: Opens phone\'s camera to identify between malignant and a non-malignant melanoma.

Melanoma occurs when the pigment-producing cells that give colour to the skin become cancerous. Melanoma develops from skin cells called Melanocytes. These are found in the deeper layers of the skin and produce a protein called melanin. Melanin protects the skin by absorbing harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
What are the causes of Melanoma?

1) New Zealand and Australia have the highest rates of melanoma in the world. 2) Melanoma is the fourth most common cancer diagnosed in New Zealand. 3) MƒÅori and Pacific people have a much lower chance of getting melanoma, but often have thicker (more serious) melanomas.
